fields: The first aircraft were made out of {{c1::wood}} with {{c2::linen}} or {{c2::canvas}}, and {{c3::steel wires}} and {{c3::tubes}}.
In the early days aiplanes were usually {{c2::biplanes}}, with the wings forming a {{c1::box}} structure.
Do lightweight materials necessarily lead to lightweight structures?
No, because low strength of the material might lead to very thick structures in order to carry a significant load.
Trinity concept: {{c1::design::d...}}, {{c2::material::m...}}, {{c3::manufacturing::m...}}
Cutting is the {{c1::removal}} and {{c2::separation}} of material from a workpiece.
In separating without chips, the workpiece is on a {{c1::die}}, a {{c2::punch}} then shears through the sheet.
In separating without chips, if the part that was sheared, also called the {{c1::slug}}, is what is discarded, the process is called {{c2::punching}}.
In separating without chips, if the part that was sheared, also called the {{c1::slug}}, is not what is discarded, the process is called {{c2::blanking}}.

In the {{c1::clearance}} [$]c[/$], the cutting edges won't be perfectly flat, but a bit inclined.

These non-flat metal surfaces are called {{c2::burrs}}, and their height increases with {{c1::clearance}}, {{c3::ductility}} of the sheet metal, and {{c4::dullness}} of tool edges.

The major processing parameters in {{c1::shearing}} are the shape of the {{c2::punch}} and {{c2::die}}, the {{c2::punch}} and {{c2::die}} materials, the {{c3::lubrication::l...}} and the {{c4::clearance}} between the {{c2::punch}} and the {{c2::die}}.

The amount of scrap material is shearing operations is very large; therefore, {{c1::nesting}} of blanks, or {{c2::proper arrangement of blanks on the sheet}}, is important, for which computer programs are often used.

In {{c1::nesting}}, the {{c3::distances between the cutting lines}} (also called {{c4::ligaments}}) has a minimum.
In shearing, a clearance between {{c1::2%::%}} and {{c1::8%::%}} is commonly used.

In shearing:
The smaller the {{c1::clearance}}, the better the quality of the sheared edge, but you can't make it too small, else the surface will be bad too.

Additionally, the {{c2::thicker}} the sheet, the {{c3::larger}} the clearance should be.
The location of the regions being sheared at any moment can be controlled by {{c1::bevelling::b...}} the {{c2::punch}} or {{c2::blade}} surfaces.
Making bevels in punches or blades symmetric helps in preventing unwanted {{c1::lateral}} forces.
During the shearing process, {{c1::bevelling}} {{c2::reduces::changes}} the forces at the beginning of the stroke.

In the context of shearing:
When the {{c3::ductility}} of the material {{c2::increases}}, the ratio between the {{c1::smooth}} surface and {{c1::rough}} surface {{c2::increases}}

In the process of nesting blanks for shearing, the following factors play a role:

The {{c2::ligaments}} should not {{c1::fail}} when the die exerts pressure on it.
The remaining material should not be {{c3::drawn}} in the hole of the die.
The remaining material should not give rise to {{c4::extra or excessive}} burrs.
The operator shouldn't get {{c5::injured}}.

In the context of shearing:
When the {{c3::thickness::t...}} or the {{c4::clearance::c...}} of the material {{c2::increases}}, the ratio between the {{c1::smooth}} surface and {{c1::rough}} surface of the slug {{c2::decreases}}
During the cutting of {{c3::brittle}} material {{c1::tiny cracks}} may occurs; these may be the starter {{c1::cracks}} for {{c2::fatigue loading::loading type}}.
{{c3::Composite}} materials tend to {{c1::delaminate}} when {{c2::punching}} or {{c2::blanking}}, making those processes unsuitable for them.
In the process of shearing, {{c2::bevelling}} refers to punches being {{c1::at small angles}} relative to the sheet.
{{c2::Separating with chips::separation method}} involves processes which remove a narrow zone (called {{c1::kerf)}} in the workpiece, and by doing so, split the workpiece in two or more parts.
Separating without chips can remove the kerf through {{c1::mechanical}} or {{c2::thermal}} removal.

In laser beam cutting:

{{c1::Reflectivity::property}} of the material: the {{c2::lower}}, the better. {{c3::Dull::D...}} and {{c4::unpolished::un...}} surfaces are preferable for this reason.
{{c5::Thermal conductivity::thermal property}} of the material should be {{c6::low}}, to make sure that only the region you're lasering is heating up and not the surrounding region.

Laser-beam cutting is widely used for drilling and cutting of metal alloys, non-metallic materials, ceramics and sometimes composite materials.

{{c4::0.025}} mm is a practical minimum for hole sizes possible with this method.
Most laser cutting processes cut flat metal sheets because the distance between the laser and the material needs to be small ({{c3::0.5 mm}}) and control in 3D for curved sheets is difficult.

In laser beam cutting:

Designs with {{c1::sharp corners}} should be avoided as they are difficult to produce.

In laser beam cutting:
{{c2::Tapering}} may occur due to the pyramid-shape of the laser: the top of the cut is a bit wider than the middle of the cut.
Two variants of laser beam cutting are:
Electrical-discharge machining and water-jet cutting
{{c2::Electrical-discharge}} machining is based on the erosion of metals by {{c1::spark discharges}}.

In {{c2::electrical-discharge machining}}, the material properties of processed metals like {{c1::hardness::h...}}, {{c1::strength::s...}} and {{c1::toughness::t...}} do not affect the removal rate because {{c3::mechanical}} energy is not involved in the process.
Regular {{c1::water-jet cutting}} can only cut soft materials such as {{c1::foam, soft rubber, etc.}}
In water-jet cutting, the speed at which the water hits the material is usually around {{c1::2-3}} Mach.

In {{c3::abrasive}} water-jet cutting, a {{c1::orifice::o...}} or {{c2::jewel::j...}} is added to the end of the jet. This means {{c4::super-hard}} particles are taken along by the water, allowing it to cut hard materials.

Most materials can be cut by an abrasive jet cutter, such as hard rubber, aluminium, titanium, composites, ceramics, etc.
However, layered composites have a large difference in strength in the in-plane direction compared to the out of-plane direction.

This difference may cause a {{c1::delamination}} problem during abrasive jet cutting, in particular when the cut is started somewhere {{c2::inside}} the plane, and not from an {{c3::edge}}.

A typical abrasive water jet cutting characteristic is the occurrence of {{c1::jet-lag}}.

As the beam of water {{c5::does not::does/doesn't}} possess any bending stiffness itself, the beam is bent whenever the jet travels over the workpiece.

In abrasive water cutting:

When cutting a corner, the pictured effect will lead to {{c2::taper}}; when this is not acceptable, the {{c4::feed rate}} (i.e. the {{c4::velocity of the water beam}}) should be {{c3::decreased}}.

Furthermore, when exiting a corner and increasing the feed rate, a {{c6::kickback}} can occur, meaning that the beam is bent differently due to the increased water velocity and damage could occur to the workpiece.
{{c2::Machining}} is the general name for all processes that remove {{c1::small chips}} from a material, often a metal alloy.
In {{c2::machining}}, the tool that removes the chip from the workpiece is called a {{c1::chisel}}.

In machining:

The {{c1::area}} of the cutting tool on which the chip pushes is called the {{c2::rake face}}.

The {{c3::rake angle}} is the angle between the line {{c4::perpendicular}} to the surface of the workpiece and the {{c2::rake face}}.

The {{c6::larger}} the rake angle (a {{c5::sharper::comparatively different}} chisel), the {{c7::lower}} the force to cut and thus the {{c7::lower}} the deformation.

However, {{c8::larger}} {{c3::rake angles}} result in {{c8::smaller}} tool angles, thus {{c8::lowering}} the strength of the chisel.

Typical angles are therefore between [$]-10^{\circ}[/$] and [$]30^{\circ}[/$].

In machining:

A small layer of material is removed by {{c1::shearing}}; the deformation of the chip generates a significant amount of heat.

Temperatures rise and measures should be taken to minimise this effect; furthermore, the chips rubs on the {{c2::rake face}}, increasing the temperature and {{c4::lowering}} the material properties of the {{c5::chisel}} and thus increasing the {{c3::wear}} rate.

{{c6::Coolant (reduces temperature)}} and {{c7::lubrication (reduces friction)}} fluids are often used, and the cutting speed is limited, so tool {{c3::wear}} becomes acceptable. A third function of the fluids is the {{c8::removal}} of the chips.

There are several reasons dividing the aircraft in structural divisions that you assemble later on. The most important reasons are:

{{c1::Production efficiency:
by splitting the work up in portions, it is easier to work on multiple parts on the same time, thereby improving efficiency obviously.::Pro...}}


{{c2::Political reasons:
consortiums like Airbus have multiple members; each of those gets work according to previously established covenants.::Po...}}

{{c3::Economical reasons:
expensive parts are added as late as possible to the main assembly (e.g. the engines). When the fuselage would be built in one station, these expensive/complex parts (e.g. the tail) would have to be stored for a very long time; obviously this is inefficient.::Ec...}}

{{c4::Accessibility and ease of production:
the accessibility of the aircraft is increased when using multiple parts as the parts are smaller and thus it's easier to work on them.::Acc...}}

{{c5::Size of the product:
many manufacturing processes have limits on the size of the product they can handle. By splitting the product into multiple parts, this is avoided. Operation and maintenance: having multiple parts means that you are able to replace single parts, rather than having to replace the full aircraft once there's a dent in something.::Si...}}

{{c6::Structural reasons:
different sections of the aircraft may require different materials to be used. If you just one single part for the whole aircraft, it'll obviously be very difficult to combine e.g. composites and metals; it's much easier to make the composite part separate from the metal, and then just join them together.::Str...}}
{{c1::Mounting}} divisions are divisions where we need to be able to {{c2::replace assembled parts}}.
{{c1::Manufacturing}} divisions or {{c1::production}} divisions are divisions where we make {{c2::permanent}} connections.

Requirements to be met by the mounting divisions are:

The mounting divisions shall be {{c1::detachable}} and {{c2::exchangeable}}.

Assembly and disassembly shall be {{c3::simple}}.

With respect to transport and handling, the parts or subassemblies should be {{c4::rigid}} and not {{c5::easily damaged}}.

Manufacturing or production divisions will be permanent joints. There are several requirements to be met:

The divisions should divide in {{c1::equally sized::sizing}} work packages.

The divisions should allow for maximum {{c2::accessibility}} of the work.

Easy {{c3::transport}} of parts within the factory is required.

The sections should account for {{c4::sizes}} of machinery, autoclaves, etc.

The joints that need not be detached should be as {{c5::light}} as possible.

Divisions should be made at {{c6::natural}} positions in the structure,
{{c6::e.g. main frames of the fuselage, the kink in the wing, etc.}}

The divisions should provide {{c7::simple}} and {{c8::cheap}} joints.

Divisions should account for the {{c9::structural shape:
divisions between single and double curved parts, no divisions across the doorway (leads to extreme difficulties when fitting everything together), limit the number of divisions in situations that need sealing afterwards (pressure cabin, fuel tank, etc.).::shape}}

{{c5::Assembly jigs}} serve two primary purposes:

Provide {{c1::support}}:
the {{c5::jig}} must obviously able to hold the subpart, and not {{c2::deform}} or {{c3::vibrate}} intensely.

{{c4::Positioning:}}
the {{c5::jigs}} are used for many aircraft, and thus the dimensions of the {{c5::jig}} and {{c4::positioning}} of the subparts should be well defined, also over a long time.

The following requirements for assembly jigs exist:


The jig should be {{c1::stiff}} and have the right {{c2::dimensional stability::type of stability}}.
{{c1::Stiff}} jigs are necessary as otherwise the assembly becomes inaccurate. For jigs that are not movable (large jigs), this requires the proper foundation of the floor.

{{c3::Accessibility:
the jig should be such that a workman can easily access all positions; this may be advanced by using a rotating jig.::Acc...}}

The jig should be {{c4::cheap}}. Usually they are {{c4::expensive}}.

The jig should not {{c5::hinder::affect}} the {{c5::removal::process}} of the finished part from the jig.

The {{c6::space occupied}} by the jig in the factory should be {{c6::minimal}}.
{{c6::This is one reason why wings, empennage, fuselage frames etc. are often built vertically.}}

Small jigs should be {{c7::moveable}}, so a {{c7::flexible}} arrangement of factory layout becomes possible.

{{c9::Temporary::type of}} tools should be {{c8::avoided}}.

{{c10::Changes}} to the jig should be easily incorporated, as well as {{c10::adjustments}} of the jig.

The {{c11::thermal expansion}} of the jig should be incorporated during the assembly. That means that the {{c12::temperature}} of the factory is controlled.
Solid riveting requires accessibility to {{c1::both sides of the material::something of the material}}
{{c1::Blind}} rivets allow for {{c2::Single-Side Assembly (SSA)}}.
Riveted joints are sensitive to {{c1::fatigue::loading mode}}.
Rivets result in {{c2::stress-concentrations}} which may initiate {{c1::fatigue cracks}}.
Riveted joints are {{c1::corrosion::chemically}} sensitive.
Riveted joints are good because they can be easily {{c1::inspected}} and {{c1::repaired}}.
Rivets are bad for aerodynamics because {{c1::it is difficult for them to obtain a smooth surface: there'll always be something sticking out from the hole. }}
Are riveted joints air- or watertight?
No.
Rivets can only be loaded in {{c1::shear}}, not in {{c2::axial}} tension (bolts can).
{{c2::Single lap}} joints are used when {{c1::aerodynamic}} requirements are not very important (as it does not create a flush product).
One disadvantage of using {{c2::single lap}} joints is their {{c1::secondary bending and the resulting extra stress concentrations.}}
Riveted {{c1::butt}} joints are used when {{c2::aerodynamic}} requirements are important because {{c2::they create a flush product.}}
{{c1::Solid}} rivets are created by holding something against it on the other side, and compressing the thing (access from both sides is required).
{{c1::Blind}} rivets are created by suction and the accompanying deformation.

Titanium fasteners similar to bolts and are very strong (especially compared to the other rivets).

Compared to solid rivets, they are not created by {{c1::squeezing}} the rivet, but rather by just {{c1::tightening}} them.

Furthermore, a very high {{c2::accuracy}} is required in fitting the rivet, compared to solid riveting.

Rivet joints can fail in three ways. These are:

{{c1::Shear}} fracture of the {{c1::rivet}}
{{c2::Bearing}} fracture of the {{c2::sheet}}
The {{c3::rivets}} may show a {{c4::2% permanent ovalisation}}.
The bearing pressure at which {{c2::the rivet deforms more than 2%}} is a material property denoted by denoted by {{c1::[$]p_{2 \%}[/$]}}
A first approximation of {{c3::[$]p_{2 \%}[/$]}} is that it is {{c1::1.6}} times the {{c2::yield}} stress of the material.

Most stuff is connected by more than one rivet, but rather with a row of rivets. Suppose we pull* on our sheet with a force per unit width [$]Q[/$] and use a rivet spacing [$]s[/$].

The rivet fails, as shown in the top of the figure, the critical ultimate load being [$]F_{u l t}[/$]

The {{c1::more}} rivets, i.e. he {{c1::smaller}} [$]s[/$], the {{c1::larger}} the applied force may be before [$]F_{u l t}[/$] is reached.

Most stuff is connected by more than one rivet, but rather with a row of rivets. Suppose we pull on our sheet with a force per unit width [$]Q[/$] and use a rivet spacing [$]s[/$].

The sheet fails, as shown in the bottom of the figure.

The rivets {{c1::decrease}} the {{c2::cross-sectional area}} of the sheet at the location of the row of rivets.

Thus, the sheet may start simply failing due to the applied tensional force.

The {{c3::more}} rivets, i.e. the {{c3::smaller}} the applied force may be before failure.
The {{c2::rivet spacing [$]s[/$]}} should be optimised to have the {{c1::rivet}} and {{c1::sheet}} fail simultaneously.

In case of two rivet rows, each rivet row carries 50% of the original load from one sheet to the other.

However, note that in case of 3 rivet rows, the load is not necessarily equally distributed over the rows.

Rather, they follow a {{c1::bathtub}} curve: {{c1::the first and last rows carry a lot of the load, the ones in between less.}}
When multiple rivet rows are used, the sheet strength is {{c1::unaffected::changed/not changed}}.
Using multiple {{c3::rivet rows}} means the {{c2::rivet pitch}} can now be {{c1::increased}} because the rivets {{c1::carry less load}}.
Bolted joints can be loaded in {{c1::shear}} and in {{c2::tension}}.
{{c1::Bolted}} joints are ideal when a {{c2::detachable}} joint is desired.
Bolts can be {{c2::pre-loaded (pretension)}} to increase {{c1::fatigue life}}.
{{c1::Bolts::Kind of joint}} are to be used in case of {{c2::thick::property}} plates.
{{c3::Bolted}} joints are often used at places with {{c1::large}} and {{c2::concentrated}} forces.
Bolts and nuts are {{c1::more::comparative}} expensive than rivets
If a bolt is not installed properly (e.g. not flush with the surface of the joint element), you {{c1::drastically increase}} the stresses as you're applying an additional {{c1::bending moment}}.
When a bolt is tightened through flanges, the bolt [$]L_B[/$] is {{c1::lengthened}} and the flanges [$]L_f[/$] are {{c2::compressed}} to the new length [$]L[/$]

Pre-loading bolts has the following effects:

{{c1::Increases::affects somehow}} minimum stress
{{c2::Greatly decreases::affects somehow}} the amplitude of the stress variations
{{c3::Does not change::affects somehow}} maximum stress

{{c3::Pre-loading bolts}} works in tensional loading because the {{c1::pre-compression of the flanges}} needs to be countered by the applied tension before the bolt {{c2::can start carrying the entire load}}.

A simple adhesive joint is shown: you simply have two plates on top of each other, connected by an adhesive.

They are primarily used for {{c1::shear}}; under {{c2::tension}} or {{c2::peel}} forces they are {{c3::weak}}.

Some advantages of adhesive bonding are:


Long {{c1::lifetime}}: it has no {{c1::holes::deformity}} and therefore no {{c1::in-plane stress concentrations::structural property}}, making them insensitive to {{c2::metal fatigue::loading mode}}.

No {{c3::weakening}} of the {{c4::sheet material}}, since it has no holes.

Resulting {{c5::smooth surfaces}} due to the lack of parts sticking out. Good for {{c6::aerodynamics::a...}}.

Allows for the joining of {{c7::different (eg metals with polymers)::type}} materials.

Bonding is less {{c8::labour intensive}} than riveting.

Bonded joints can be {{c9::corrosion}} resistant, and {{c10::air- and liquid tight}}.

Some disadvantages of adhesive bonding are:

{{c4::Manufacturing}} processes are {{c3::complicated}}.

Extensive {{c2::pre-treatment::pre...}} is needed.

Bond lines are very {{c1::thin (often in the order of 1mm)}}.

This requires high {{c5::accuracy}} of the parts to be joined.

Bonded joints {{c6::are not::are/aren't}} suited for disassembly.

Bonded joints may only be loaded by {{c7::shear}}, not by {{c7::tension}}.
The loads in an adhesive {{c1::are not::are/aren't}} uniform.
When tension is applied to two plates bonded by an adhesive, only {{c1::shear}} forces deform the plates due to the {{c1::shear}} strains in the adhesive.
When tension is applied to two plates bonded by an adhesive, the shear strains of the adhesive cause shear stresses on the plates that follow a {{c1::baththub}} curve.

Increasing the joint length of an adhesive joint:

{{c1::slightly inceases}} the joint strength
{{c2::decreases}} the average shear stress [$]\tau_{avg}[/$]
{{c3::does not:does/doesn't}} reduce the maximum stress [$]\tau_{max}[/$]
In order to reduce the maximum stress of an adhesive joint, we use {{c1::slanted}} edges or {{c2::scarf}} joints.

For thermoplast adhesives, the following steps are taken:

1. {{c1::Pre-treatment}} of the surfaces that need to be bonded.
2. {{c1::Applying the heated adhesive::Appl...}} to the surfaces.
3. {{c1::Joining}} of the surfaces.
4. {{c1::Cooling}} of the joint.

For thermoset adhesives, the following steps are taken:

1. {{c1::Pre-treatment}} of the surfaces that need to be bonded.
2. {{c1::Applying the heated adhesive::Appl...}} to the surfaces.
3. {{c1::Joining}} of the surfaces.
4. {{c1::Curing}} of the joint.
{{c1::Welding}} is the process of {{c2::locally melting material in narrow adjacent regions}} next to the {{c1::weld}} line, and then {{c2::solidifying the metal together.}}

Welding has a number of advantages:


The joint is {{c1::continuous}}, as opposed to e.g. {{c1::the discrete load-paths found in a riveted joint.}}

Welded joints are often {{c2::butt}} joints, not {{c2::overlap}} joints as for bonding and riveting; this results in a {{c2::smooth}} joint (important for aerodynamic and hydrodynamic surfaces).

Welded joints {{c3::are::are/aren't}} watertight and airtight.

Welding has a number of disadvantages:


The welding processs heats and liquefies some of the material, {{c1::adversely}} affecting the heat-treatment of the sections being joined.
High-quality materials that use heat-treatment to attain high strength are therefure usually {{c1::unsuitable}} for welding, which is one of the main reasons why welding is {{c1::rarely}} chosen above riveting in aircraft industry.

A {{c2::consistent}} weld quality is difficult to get and to guarantee.

{{c3::Thin-walled::type of}} steel plates cannot be easily welded together.
{{c1::Quality}} is the {{c2::totality of characteristics}} of an entity that bears on its ability to satisfy stated and implied needs.
{{c1::Quality policy}} is the {{c2::overall intention and direction}} of an organisation with regard to {{c2::quality}}, as formally expressed by top management.

{{c1::Quality management}} are all {{c2::activities of the overall management function}} that determines the quality policy {{c3::objectives and responsibilities}}, and implement them within the quality system by means such as:
quality planning, quality control, quality assurance and quality improvement.
Quality management is the responsibility of {{c1::all levels of management}} but must be led by {{c2::top management}}. Its implementation involves all members of the organisation.
{{c1::Quality planning}} are the activities that establish the {{c2::objectives and requirements}} for quality and for the {{c2::application}} of quality system elements.
{{c1::Quality control}} are the {{c2::operational techniques}} and {{c2::activities}} that are used to {{c3::fulfill requirements}} for quality.

{{c1::Quality assurance}} are all the {{c2::planned and systematic activities}} implemented within the quality system, and demonstrated as needed, to provide {{c3::adequate confidence that an entity will fulfil requirements for quality}}.
{{c1::Quality system}} is the {{c2::organisational structure::or...}}, {{c3::procedures::pro...}}, {{c4::processes::pro...}} and {{c5::resources::re...}} needed to implement quality management.

{{c1::Total quality management}} is the {{c2::management approach}} of an organisation, centred on {{c1::quality}}, based on the participation of all its members and aiming at long-term success through customer satisfaction, and benefits to all members of the organisation and to society.
{{c1::Quality manual}} is the document stating the {{c2::quality policy}} and describing the {{c2::quality system}} of an organisation.

{{c1::Quality audit}} is the {{c2::systematic and independent examination}} to determine whether quality activities and related results comply with planned arrangements and whether these arrangements are {{c3::implemented effectively and are suitable to achieve objectives}}.

{{c1::Non-conformance reports}} are reports made by an inspector who checks that all the parts {{c5::conform with their required design}}.

This is checked by several types of inspection. The report contains a lot of {{c2::technical data about the product}}, the {{c3::detected flaws}}, the {{c4::applied testing methods}}.

Non-destructive testing includes methods such as:

{{c1::Ultrasonic: soundwaves that travel through the material::Ult...}}

{{c2::Tap-test: acoustic sounds are created by tapping on the product, which can be heard by an amplifier.::Tap...}}

{{c3::Fokker bondtest: a vibration is induced; the variation of this can be measured.::Fok...}}

{{c4::Penetrant: this allows for visually seeing cracks on the surface by use of color aids.::Pe...}}

{{c5::Magnetic particles: this uses metal dust.::Mag...}}

{{c6::Eddy current uses electric field interactions.::Ed...}}

{{c7::Thermography uses temperature differences.::The...}}

{{c8::Visual inspection::Vi...}}

{{c1::Lean manufacturing}} is the dynamic, knowledge driven, and customer-focused process, through which all people in a defined enterprise continuously eliminate {{c2::waste}} with the goal of creating value.

In the context of lean manufacturing,

{{c1::Waste}} is anything that uses {{c2::resources}}, but does not {{c2::add value}} to the product or service.
{{c1::Stakeholders}} are the parties that have an interest in {{c2::value creation}}.
Lean manufacturing is knowledge-driven because:

the entire workface has to participate, from top-level managers to low-level labour workers.
The low-level labour workers are especially important as they see waste happening in real time, and thus are best suited in eliminating it.
A {{c1::pull}} market is when the {{c2::end customer}} is the ultimate goal and companies respond to {{c2::customer}} demands.

In the context of lean manufacturing, eight types of waste can be distinguished:

1. {{c1::Overproduction,
which means producing more, sooner or faster than required by the next process. This is waste, as you need to store the materials and products.::Over...}}

2. {{c2::Waiting time,
which is the time a worker has to wait while the machine is processing.::Wait...}}

3. {{c3::Work in Progress (WIP) or inventory.
Inventory is material between operations, i.e. material that's not currently being worked on but it needs to be stored anyway, another form of waste.::Work...}}

{{c4::4. Processing:
unnecessary processing steps or product.::Pro...}}

{{c5::5. Transportation:
transportation should always be eliminated or minimised.::Tra...}}

{{c6::6. Movement or motion:
everytime a worker has to move, you have to think: "we've just wasted 10 seconds from the worker having to walk to the bathroom. We should just allow people to piss and poo on the workfloor, that' ll reduce those times."::Move...}}

{{c7::7. Rework:
extra work to be done cause the first time a defective product was made.::Re...}}

{{c8::8. Underutilising people:
for example, some people can write very good production plans. But, you'd utilise them even more if you start letting them bring coffee to everyone as well, unlocking their full potential. You always need to make sure people are working at their highest capability.::Under...}}

The three phases of value creation are:

1. {{c1::
Value identification:
Defining needs and requirements with all stakeholders
::Id...}}

2. {{c2::
Value proposition:
Desiging the product (proposing the value)
Pro...}}

3. {{c3::
Value delivery:
Produce and deliver the product
::Del...}}
One of the methods inside the context of lean principles is {{c2::5S (five steps)}} - this is used primarily to {{c1::eliminate waste}}.

The 5S (five steps) method in lean manufacturing is as follows:

1. {{c1::
Sort:
at this stage all the items on the workplace have to be looked at and be segregated. The necessary and unnecessary items are separated, and unnecessary items will be removed.
::segregation}}

2. {{c2::
Simplify:
randomly located items are identified and arranged. There have to be established designated areas for all the items.
::arrangement}}

3. {{c3::
Scrub/Shine:
the workplace is cleaned on a regular basis and the machinery is cleaned on a daily basis.
::clean}}

4. {{c4::
Standardise:
the improved methods and changes are documented, and visual control agreements for labelling and quantity levels are established. This has to ensure a frequent reflection on the previous three steps of 5S.
::document}}

5. {{c5::
Sustain:
the changes are developed and utilised. The established results should motivate people to keep to the changes and improvements and to use the 5S principles consistently themselves.
::continue}}

{{c1::Just-in-time (JIT)}} is the system where items are delivered {{c2::exactly when required}}, and not {{c3::a moment later (then it'd be too late)}} or {{c4::too soon (as then you'd need to store it)}}.
{{c1::Load levelling}} means ensuring that all manufacturing stages take {{c2::an approximately equal amount of work, as to avoid bottle necks}}.
The pictured lean manufacturing method is called {{c1::Takt time}}.
{{c1::Cellular manufacturing}} is the process of creating assembly lines out of cells of multiple types of equipment that allow for {{c2::variations in products}}.
Aircraft parts are manufactured in {{c2::batches}}, but the assembly of an aircraft is organised in line {{c1::production}}.

{{c2::Line production}} is the intermediate system between a {{c1::dock-like system}} (as used for ships) and {{c1::mass-production}}, where millions of parts are moved continuously through the production facilities.

In {{c2::line production}}, the parts do move throughout the facility, but they move at {{c1::specific time intervals}} to the next spot in the production line (called {{c3::station}}), so it's not a {{c1::continuous}} movement.

Batch size depends on a number of parameters:

{{c2::Delivery interval (time between deliveries)::Del...}} or {{c3::number of aircraft produced::quantity}} (in e.g. a year). The higher this number, the shorter the {{c2::delivery interval}}, and the larger the batch size.

The number of {{c1::identical}} parts in one aircraft: the more, the larger the batch size.

The {{c4::size}} of a part: the larger the {{c4::size}}, the more stock area is needed, which also costs money.

The {{c6::higher::comparative}} the price of a part, the lower the batch size.

The ratio {{c7::manufacturing time/change-over time}}:
if the {{c7::change-over time}} is large, then it costs a lot of time to set up the machines to change from one operation to another. Then you'd want to increase the batch size, as apparently it takes a lot of time to switch operations: if you'd have to produce small batches frequently, this would start consuming a lot time (cause between the production of batches, the machine will probably do something else, so it'll need to switch operation conditions every time).

A schematic assembly line is shown: the assembly line consists of multiple stations.



At each station, the same crew performs the same tasks at subsequent aircraft over and over again.

The {{c2::allocated time}} for these tasks is {{c1::fixed}} and is the {{c1::same}} for all stations.

When the time is passed, all aircraft move to the next station (moving the aircraft is often performed at night).

This time interval between two movements of the aircraft is called the {{c3::delivery interval}}, as it's essentially the time between two {{c3::deliveries (after the last station, the aircraft is moved to delivery after all)}}.

The advantages of line production are:


{{c1::Minimal transport (saves cost)::Tr...}}

{{c2::Simple planning::Pl...}}

{{c3::Good indication of progress (delays are obvious)::Pro...}}

{{c4::Maximal equal shaped products::Eq...}}

{{c5::Maximal routine forming per crew::Rout...}}
The learning curve of aircraft assembly assembly crews follows a {{c1::exponentially decaying::type of}} curve.

[$] E_{N}=K \cdot N^{s} [/$]
[$] E_{N}[/$] : effort to build n-th aircraft
[$]K[/$] : effort to build first aircraft
[$]s[/$] : reduction factor or slope constant
The {{c1::break-even point}} is the aircraft number at which the total {{c2::accumulated revenues}} equals the total {{c2::accumulated costs}}.

In machining, the back face of the chisel (which doesn't directly carve the the workpiece) is called the {{c1::flank}}.

When the chisel is removed, the workpiece springs back because of elastic deformation. This rubs the workpiece against the {{c1::flank}}, and causes friction and heat.
This can be attenuated/remedied using:

{{c3::Cooling::C...}}

Application of {{c2::lubricant::l...}}

A lower {{c4::cutting speed::cu...}}

A larger {{c5::flank angle::fl...}}, a typical value of which is {{c6::6}} degrees.

In machining, wear of the chisel is found on the rake face and the flank face.

{{c1::Rake}} face wear is is defined by {{c2::crater depth (KT)::cr...}}.

{{c3::Flank}} face wear is defined by the {{c4::width of the wear (VB)::wi...}}.

The thickness of machined products' walls has a minimum.

Thin walls are {{c1::(elastically) deformed when forces are exerted on them::altered}}, resulting in inaccurate thicknesses.

The available thickness is thus depending on the {{c2::stiffness::property}} of the product (both in shape and material).

For aluminium the minimum thickness is in the order of {{c3::millimetres::unit}}.

The life span of a machining chisel can be expressed in several ways:

Life {{c1::time::ti...}}: the {{c1::amount of time}} that a cutting edge cuts

Life {{c2::length::le...}}: the {{c2::distance}} that a cutting edge cuts

Life {{c3::amount::am...}}: the {{c3::amount}} of products made

Machining chips come in three shapes:

{{c1::continuous::con...}} chip, {{c2::segmented::seg...}} chip and {{c3::discontinuous::dis...}} chip.

Concerning the chips of machined materials:

{{c1::Aluminium alloys}} are {{c3::very easy::difficulty}} to machine; however, they may create continuous chips. This can be avoided by picking high {{c2::cutting speeds::speed}}, small {{c2::rake}} angles and large {{c2::relief/flank}} angles, so that large deformations of chips occur. When hard particles are present in aluminium alloys, higher wear results.

{{c4::Steels}} are a very broad group of materials, some are easy to machine and some difficult. When the shearing is facilitated by the alloying elements (e.g. these act as {{c5::stress raisers}} in the shear zone), the machining is improved.

{{c6::Austenitic stainless}} steels are {{c7::generally difficult::difficulty}} to machine; {{c8::vibrations}} can be a problem, necessitating machine tools with high {{c9::stiffness}}.
{{c10::Ferritic stainless}} steels have a {{c11::good::good/bad}} machinability.
{{c12::Martensitic}} steels are abrasive.

{{c13::Fibre reinforced composites}} have a very {{c14::abrasive::material property}} component (e.g. class or carbon), making it {{c14::difficult::difficulty}} to machine.

The main requirement on cutting tootls is being {{c1::hard::h...}} when it is {{c1::hot::h...}}.

This is also known as {{c1::hot hardness (HT)::h...}}.

When designing cutting tools for hot hardness (HT), the base consists of a hard metal (or {{c1::cemented carbide/nitride}}), on top of which coatings of even harder {{c1::carbides/nitrides}} are layered to increase the hardness of the tool.

The reason {{c1::cemented carbides/nitrides}} are not used as a base is because they are too {{c2::brittle::material property}}.

Machining is a process characterized by {{c2::universal::u...}} tools that are {{c2::not dependent on the product}}.

The product series for machining is often {{c1::small to moderate::size}} and it {{c1::is::is/isn't}} preferred for mass production.

The only machining cost that is high relative to other processes is the {{c3::equipment::e...}} cost, all others are low.

For machining,

An analysis of the costs vs. cutting speed may be performed as follows:

The faster the cutting speed, the less hours are required for production, thus the lower {{c3::man::m...}} and {{c3::machine::...}} cost.

However, higher cutting speeds lead to more {{c1::wear}}, thus increasing the {{c2::tool and tool change}} cost.

{{c1::Turning}} is machining where {{c3::the tool is stationary, but the workpiece is rotating around its cylindrical axis}}.

Chip break grooves or chip breakers may be used to ensure {{c2::discontinuous}} chips.

{{c1::Milling}} is machining where the workpiece is {{c2::stationary}}, and the tool is {{c2::rotating}}.

{{c1::
{{c3::Slab}} milling is where the rotation axis is {{c5::parallel}} to the machined surface.

{{c4::Face}} milling is where the rotation axis is {{c6::perpendicular}} to the machines surface.
}}

{{c1::Drilling}} is machining where the workpiece is stationary, but the tool is rotating about the axis perpendicular to the machined surface; it is also translating into the machined surface. It is used to create {{c1::holes}}.

{{c1::Grinding}} is machining where the workpiece is stationary, but the tool is rotating about the axis parallel to the machined surface.

Temperatures may get very high; however, as the chips are carried away by the tool, most of the heat is {{c2::conducted (sparks)}} away.
During metal casting, the metal is liquefied and poured into a {{c1::mould}} that has the shape of the final product.
During metal casting, the liquefied metal is poured into a {{c1::pouring cup}}, after which it goes down a {{c2::sprue}}, and via a {{c3::runner}} system into the {{c4::mould cavity}}.
During metal casting, {{c1::risers}} are present to allow for liquefied metal to be supplied when {{c2::the metal starts shrinking inside the mould cavity.}}

During metal casting, cooling of the metal is an important aspect:

First, {{c1::shrinkage}} allowance is required; the mould should be {{c1::larger::comparative size}} than the product needs to be, to take into account that the metal will {{c1::shrink}} during solidification.

During metal casting, the {{c5::runner::r...}} system should obviously be designed in such a way that the cavity is filled in the right way:

No {{c1::gasses}} are trapped in the cavity,
{{c3::Contaminants}} (e.g. oxides) do not end up in the product
The flow remains {{c2::laminar}}
The {{c4::solidification::physical process}} of the metal does not prevent the filling of the mould.
During metal casting, only {{c1::gradual}} thickness changes are allowed, to prevent {{c2::hot tears}} from occurring, which happen when the mould prevents the product from {{c3::shrinking}}.

During metal casting, the {{c6::mould}} should preferably have a {{c1::smaller}} thickness at the bottom than at the top, to prevent {{c2::micro-porosities}} from occuring, which happen due to metal {{c3::solidifying::physical process}} too early, which prevents {{c4::new metal being supplied from the {{c5::risers}} to certain areas.}}
During metal casting, {{c1::casting factors}} are mandated by regulations, to address {{c2::uncertainties}} in material properties.

For metal casting, compared to forging, the mechanical properties are usually {{c1::less::more/less}} for cast products, and the minimum achievable thickness is {{c2::higher::higher/lower}}. Casting is {{c3::cheaper::cheaper/more expensive}} than forging.

Sand casting relies on sand as filling the flanks.

It consists of two main components, a {{c1::cope}} on top and a {{c2::drag}} on the bottom.

The seam between them is the {{c3::parting}} line.

In sand casting:

Both the cope and the drag are surrounded by a {{c1::flask}}.

This flask is filled completely with sand; several holes are made into this sand to create a {{c3::pouring::p...}} cup, a {{c3::sprue::spr...}}, a {{c4::gate::g...}}, {{c5::risers::ri...}} and a {{c6::vent}}, which {{c7::transports gases and hot air from the mould}}.

There is also a core of sand, this aims to create a {{c2::hollow}} product. {{c2::(e.g. if you would want to create a soda can by sand casting, you'd include a core to create the hollowness inside).}}

Metal casting moulds either rely on {{c1::gravity}} or on {{c2::pressure}} forces to make the liquefied metal flow into the correct places.

They are either {{c3::perishable (i.e. destroyed after one casting)::per...}} (also called {{c3::expendable}}) or {{c3::reusable::re...}} (also called {{c3::permanent}}).

{{c4::Composite}} moulds consist of two or more {{c5::different metals}}.

Sand casting relies on {{c1::gravity::force}}, and is {{c2::perishable::type of casting}}:

{{c2::no high pressures are applied to move the liquid (this would destroy the mould, as sand is very brittle (it's a ceramic)), and after casting, the sand needs to be completely removed to obtain the product, so you destroy your mould.}}

In {{c3::investment}} casting, first products are made of {{c1::wax}}.

These are then coated by {{c2::ceramic}}; the assembly of products is heated up, making the {{c1::wax}} disappear.

Now the {{c2::ceramic}} mould can be filled with molten metal.

In sand casting, 

The sand needs to have the strength to not {{c1::collapse}} during the process.

It needs to have the {{c2::permeability::p...}} to allow gasses and steam to escape during the process.

It needs to have the {{c3::collapsibility::c...}} to allow the casting to {{c4::shrink}} during the process thereby preventing defects as hot tearing.

Metal casting is governed by the laws of continuity and Bernoulli.

These two laws result in a design wherein the {{c2::sprue}} diameter should {{c1::decrease}} when the metal falls downward and the speed increases due to gravity.

Whether laminar or turbulent flow occurs depends on the Reynolds number.

Turbulent flows give rise to the formation of {{c3::dross}} (foam on the metal surface), which is unwanted.

In metal casting: 

After casting, the mould and metal are cooled; this causes a shrinkage of something in the order of {{c2::5%}} depending on the metal used.

Furthermore, allowing the mould to {{c3::collapse}} when the metal has become solid reduces the occurrence of {{c4::hot tears}}.

This is only possible for {{c1::perishable::pe...}} moulds and not for {{c1::permanent::pe...}} moulds.
In metal casting, to allow the product to be removed after casting, {{c1::draft}} angles are used.

Since there are many variants in metal casting, it is difficult to formulate general characteristics.

However, some general remarks are possible:

A {{c2::rough::physical property}} surface quality makes it {{c3::easier::easier/harder}} for gases to escape, but means {{c4::more::more/less}} finishing processes are needed.

The time needed for producing a product by an expendable mould is generally {{c1::larger::larger/smaller}} than when using a permanent mould {{c1::(as then you don't have to build the mould as well)}}.

A significant number of process variants exist in metal casting.

When the sand in sand casting is replaced with plaster or ceramic, the process is called plaster-mould casting or ceramic-mould casting.

Changing the sand with plaster or ceramic {{c1::reduces::changes}} the {{c2::permeability::physical property}} and thus attention must be paid to the venting of the gasses.

{{c1::Shell-mould}} casting is another process variant.

We first heat up a pattern, and the bottom of the box we have some sand with {{c2::resin}} binder.
We then turn the box around, and the sand and {{c2::resin}} now lay on the heated pattern.
Due to the temperature, they start mixing and form a {{c1::shell}} around the pattern.
The box is turned upside down again, such that the sand that did not become a {{c1::shell}} is removed.
The {{c1::shell}} is then removed from the pattern, and we now have a nice mould.
Combining it with an identical mould allows for a nice assembly of a cope and a drag.
{{c1::Centrifugal}} casting may be used to cast more or less rotational symmetrical products with a large hollow core (e.g. cylinders).

In {{c1::revolve}} casting, the product is toppled (turned) over three axes, allowing more freedom of shape. The wall thickness of the product is defined by the time the inertia forces are active on the mould.

When the liquid metal is {{c2::pressurised by hydraulics or pneumatics::acted upon}} and fed into the cavity of the permanent moulds, the process is called {{c1::pressure-die}} casting or simply {{c1::die}} casting.

The {{c2::pressure}} is used to solve possible gas venting problems, and promotes the flow of the liquid, allowing thinner and more complex shapes to be cast (the shape must still be tapered, so {{c3::draft}} angles still need to be used).

Polymers come in two different flavors:

{{c1::Thermosets}} require a {{c2::chemical reaction}} to form {{c2::molecular networks}} during processing.

{{c3::Thermoplasts}} show a {{c4::physical change from solid to liquid}} during processing.
Polymers are only used in aerospace structural elements when they are {{c1::reinforced with short fibres (e.g. glass or carbon fibres)::modified somehow}}.

An important parameter during the processing of liquids is the {{c1::viscosity}} of the liquid.

{{c2::Metals::M...}} have a low {{c1::viscosity}}.

{{c2::Monomers::M...}} also show a similar low {{c1::viscosity}}.

{{c2::Polymers::P...}} show a large variation in {{c1::viscosity}} from (high to very high).
When reinforcements are added to them, the {{c1::viscosity}} increases even more.

Low viscosity liquids can be poured into a mould cavity, whereas high viscosity liquids need to be forced into it.
At a certain point the viscosity becomes so high that it's not even really a liquid anymore, but more a soft solid.

In terms of processing, {{c1::injection::i...}} moulding is seen as a liquid phase process, whereas {{c1::compression::c...}} moulding is seen as a solid phase process.
In polymer injection moulding, {{c1::extrusion}} is the process of forcing the polymer out of a {{c2::nozzle}} or {{c2::die}} using a {{c3::screw}} to heat the material and move it.

Concerning thermoplastic polymer extrusion:

Thermoplasts need to be {{c1::heated::physical process}} before they can be processed.

Concerning thermoplastic polymer extrusion:

Inside of a thermoplastic extrusion screw system, {{c1::granulates}} (near cylindrical things with a size of several millimetres) are added to the added to the thermoplastic material;
the screw rotates the {{c1::granulates}} and {{c2::compresses::com...}} them and {{c2::shears::she...}} them;
this causes {{c3::uniform heating}} of the thermoplastic polymer, allowing it to fill the mould.

If necessary, the screw can act as a plunger to push the last remaining material into the mould (the screw is moved to the left).

Concerning thermoset extrusion screws:

For thermoset polymers, the screw {{c1::is not::is/is not}} tapered.

The {{c2::shearing::she...}} of the polymers is sufficient to break the cross-links between the polymers, breaking the thermoset down.
When too much heat is generate due to the {{c2::shearing}} of the polymer, cooling is needed.
Thermoplastic extrusion screws {{c1::are::are/are not}} tapered.
Thermoplastic polymers are {{c1::molten::process}}, processed, and then {{c1::solidified::process}}.

For {{c4::thermoset}} polymers, the internal chemical {{c1::crosslinks}} are broken so that only {{c2::monomers}} are left over, these {{c2::monomers}} are processed, and then {{c1::crosslinks}} are created again (also called{{c3::curing}}).

In injection moulding, {{c1::die swell}} may occur.

This refers to the event that happens when the {{c2::thermoplast::kind of polymer}} leaves the nozzle or die; as it's significantly {{c1::compressed::state}} inside the die, it may {{c1::expand::process}} considerably when leaving it.

As injection moulding requires pressure, the {{c2::size::property}} of the press that holds the mould system and the achievable press {{c3::force}} determine the {{c1::maximum size}} of the composite component.

The maximum component size is in the order of square {{c4::meters::units}}.

{{c5::Larger::comparative}} components require {{c5::larger::same comparative}} presses, becoming economically infeasible.

Furthermore, a {{c6::draft}} angle should be used on surfaces parallel to the opening direction of the press to allow for component removal without damaging its surface.

In polymer injection moulding:

Stiffening elements may be included in shells (e.g. stiffeners).



However, as the polymers shrink when heated, dents (also called {{c1::sink}} marks) may occur on the outside of the shell where the stiffening elements are placed. This is often undesired out of aesthetic reasons and these should thus be avoided.

During the flow of either the liquefied thermoplast or thermoset (also called {{c1::resin}} when liquefied), they may merge when the mould has multiple injection points.

This leads to {{c2::knitlines}}:
reinforcements {{c4::do not::do/do not}} cross such a {{c3::knitline}}, but align {{c4::parallel::parallel/perpendicular}} to it, resulting in {{c4::weak::strong/weak}} sections in the product.

In polymer injection moulding:

During mixing with the resin in an extruder, the added reinforcement (which is necessary for structural aerospace applications) usually breaks into smaller pieces.

When the size of the fiber becomes {{c2::similar}} in all directions, it loses its {{c1::reinforcementness::property}}: one or two directions of the additive should be much {{c2::larger::larger/smaller}} than the other(s).

In polymer injection moulding:

On a structural level, reinforcements (e.g. metallic inserts or laminated sections made of continuous fibers) can be inserted in the mould system.

During the injection of the polymer the inserts/laminates are surrounded by the polymer, called {{c1::overmoulding}} (so that when you take the product out of the mould, {{c2::the inserts remain inside the product::what happens}}).

In this way, complex structures can be manufactured in one run, and making complex structures in this way is very cost effective compared to assembled structures.
In aerospace, often {{c1::glass::material}} fibers are added to polymers to {{c2::increase::alter}} its {{c2::mechanical::type of property}} properties.
In the processing of {{c3::thermoplastics::type of polymer}}, a {{c2::tapered::physical shape}} screw ensures that {{c1::the granulates shear and create frictional heat::process}}.

For polymer injection moulding, due to the {{c1::high::high/low}} equipment and mould cost, this process is only beneficial for {{c1::large::large/small}} product series and the cycle time (time to produce a component) must be {{c1::low::low/high}}.

Injection moulding has {{c2::high::high/low}} equipment costs because:

{{c1::High forces are needed to fill the mould cavity. This results in a press which must be strong. The moulds should also withstand high forces and are made of hardened steel.}}

Polymer injection moulding has:

{{c1::Small}} material waste and
{{c2::Low}} and {{c2::reproducible}} shrinkage, and therefore:

{{c3::High}} accuracy
{{c4::Short}} cycle times.
{{c1::Plastic}} deformation of metals are introduced by dislocation movements due to external forces, whereas {{c1::elastic}} deformation is merely the bonds between atoms acting as springs.

Some specific metal alloys show {{c1::superplastic}} behaviour. Under special conditions, very {{c2::large}} strains can be created under very {{c2::small}} loads; instead of crystal deformation and dislocation movements, the crystals {{c3::slide along}} each other.

For fiber reinforced polymers, the maximum deformations of fibres are very small, so large deformations in fibre directions are prevented.

In {{c1::intra-ply}} shear, the fibres within one prepreg layer are sheared and rotates w.r.t. each other.

For fiber reinforced polymers, the maximum deformations of fibres are very small, so large deformations in fibre directions are prevented.

In {{c1::inter-ply shear}}, the fibers are sheared or slipped between multiple layers.

In metal forming processes:

When you deform a material, its initial deformation is elastic, so it will {{c1::spring back}} when you release it, even if there was plastic deformation afterwards.

 If it doesn't do this, you'll create {{c2::residual}} stresses instead.
Plastic deformation of metal sheets is improved when it is performed at elevated temperatures, as the required {{c1::loads}} {{c3::reduce}} and the {{c2::failure limits::fai...}} {{c3::increase}}.

Sheet metal forming processes are about forming sheet metals. The shape of a part is described using a classification of parts; this greatly influences which sheet metal forming process can be used.

{{c1::Undeformed}} parts: these sheets are mere cut-outs.

Single curved parts with large bend radius. Think of {{c2::fuselage sections::structural part}}.

Single curved parts, with a small bend radius. Think of {{c3::stiffeners::structural part}}.

Double curved parts, with large bend radii: the radii in orthogonal directions are large. This occurs for example on {{c4::the cockpit of a fuselage::structural part}}. 

Double curved parts, with one large and one small bend radius. Think of {{c5::ribs in wings::structural part}}.

Double curved parts, with (locally) small bend radii in orthogonal directions.
{{c1::Rubber forming}} is the most important process in the aircraft industry and accounts for about {{c2::50}}% of all sheet metal parts, main reason being {{c3::low costs}}.

The basic idea behind rubber forming:

You have your flat sheet laying on a {{c1::die}}, and a rubber {{c2::press}} acts on it and gives it the desired shape.

In rubber forming, the part of rubber press that actually touches the piece is a thin slab, and is replaced due to high wear.

The part above it, which does not get replaced, can consist of {{c1::rubber}} or {{c1::fluid}}.

In rubber forming, male and female dies can be used. Here are some of their properties:



Female dies are used to create {{c2::valleys}} in the product.

The complexity of the products that can be created by female dies is {{c3::high::large/small}}.
The complexity of the products that can be created by male dies is {{c3::small::large/small}}.

Female dies {{c1::do::do/do not}} require to be machined afterwards.
Male dies {{c1::do not::do/do not}} require to be machined afterwards.
Rubber forming requires {{c1::large::large/small}} press forces, leading to {{c1::long::long/short}} cycle times (few minutes per product).
Rubber forming {{c1::isn't::is/isn't}} used for larger product series (larger than 100-2500 parts) due to the {{c1::long::long/short}} process time.

Bending theory is based on the following assumptions:

a) The material is {{c1::isotropic}} and {{c2::homogeneous}}.

b) The stress-strain curve is {{c3::congruent::con...}}, i.e. the compressive and tensile curves are {{c3::symmetrical::s...}} about the origin.
So: [$](-\epsilon,-\sigma)=(\epsilon, \sigma)[/$].

c) The bending is performed by a {{c4::pure bending moment}}.

d) {{c6::Cross sections}} remain {{c5::flat}} during bending.

e) In the bend zone, the {{c8::bend radius}} has a {{c7::constant}} value .

f) The sheet material has no {{c9::internal stresses}} at the start of the bending process.

From bending theory, it can be proven that:

The stress in the centre line of the bend zone is {{c2::zero}}; this is defined as the {{c1::neutral axis}}.
The strain does not necessarily have to be {{c2::zero}}!

From bending theory, it can be proven that:

The strain is {{c1::proportional}} to the {{c2::distance to the neutral axis}}.

In fact, the maximum strain can be easily computed to be [$]t/(2 \cdot r)[/$] Why?

In bending,

The {{c1::spring back}} angle [$]\gamma[/$] is defined as the difference between the angle {{c2::over which we bend a material::specific angle}} [$]\alpha_{0}[/$] and {{c2::the one it returns to::other angle}} [$]\alpha_{1}[/$].

Due to {{c1::spring back}}, also the {{c3::bending radius}} will increase; if it's not fully released, {{c4::internal stresses}} remain.

Bending is usually performed on a {{c1::press brake}}.

The machine has a stationary lower bed and a moving upper bed or ram.

A bending die is placed on the lower bed and a bending radius is attached to the upper beam.
Both can be replaced easily and are universal.

In plastic deformation resulting from bending, the strain varies {{c1::linearly}} with distance from the {{c2::neutral axis}}, but the stress close to the {{c2::neutral axis}} varies much more because {{c3::it is in the bend zone}}.
The image corresponds to a process called {{c1::guided}} bending.

A large variety of bending dies exist:

In {{c1::V-die}} or {{c1::air}} bending, the sheet is {{c2::bent intowards a cavity, but does not completely fill the cavity}}.

In {{c3::matched die}} bending, the sheet is {{c4::bent intowards the cavity until it touches the walls}}.

In {{c5::wiping}} or {{c5::wipe}} bending, the material is {{c6::bent over a rigid thing on top of it}}.

a) is V-die or air bending
b) is matched die bending
d) is wipe bending
The process shown in this image corresponds to {{c1::rubber}} bending.
Shear forces cause a bending moment that {{c1::varies::changes}} with {{c2::distance}}.

{{c1::Roll}} bending creates {{c2::homogeneous}} bending moments on metal sheets because {{c3::every part on the sheet experiences the same shear forces.}}

This is done to counteract non-{{c2::homogeneous}} bending moments created by static shear forces used in other methods.
One problem of {{c1::roll}} bending is that the {{c3::spring back}} is large due to the large {{c2::[$]r / t[/$]}} ratio, meaning you need to {{c1::roll}} it several times.

Bending operations product series range from small to large and are process dependent.

V-die bending, matched die and rubber die bending require {{c4::large::large/small}} labour costs and thus are used for {{c5::small::large/small}} product series.

Wipe bending and guide bending are used for {{c6::large::large/small}} product series because they can {{c7::be automated::altered}}, leading to low {{c7::flexibility}}.
Bending operations are, generally speaking, {{c3::cheap}}.
Bending operations need precise {{c1::alignment of the tools}}, increasing the {{c2::costs}}.
{{c1::Stretch}} forming is required for sheets that need curvature in two directions with large radii.

{{c1::Stretch forming::process}} is occasionally used for single curved parts.

This is e.g. done when a complex shape is combined with high tolerances, such as leading edges of wings.

In stretch forming:

The geometrical limits to the radii of the shells that can be achieved are determined by the maximum {{c3::applicable strain per cycle}} and the number of {{c4::cycles needed}}.

Between two stretch forming cycles, the material is {{c1::heat treated}} to remove the effects of {{c2::strain hardening}}.

The tooling of the deep drawing process consists of three elements: the punch, the drawing die and the blank holder.

The {{c1::punch}} provides the shape to the part: it is a product related tool.
The {{c2::drawing die}} assures that the material in the flange of the blank is transformed into the product wall.

In the deep drawing process:

The clearance between the punch and the drawing die, the gap, should be larger than the material thickness, but not too large. If the gap becomes too large, {{c1::wrinkling}} over the die radius is possible.

In the deep drawing process:

The surfaces of the blank holder and the drawing die should be {{c1::smooth}} because {{c2::the blank should be able to move towards the punch with the lowest possible friction (= lowest possible drawing/punch force)}}.

{{c1::Often, these surfaces get a special surface finish or are polished. }}

{{c2::Both surfaces are lubricated in order ot reduce the friction even more.}}
The forming limits of deep drawn parts are expressed by a maximum value of the {{c1::depth-to-width ratio}} or with the {{c1::deep drawing ratio [$]\beta[/$]}}.

The {{c1::deep drawing}} ratio is defined as {{c3::
the ratio of the maximum original blank diameter [$]D_{0}[/$] and the punch diameter [$]d[/$] for that situation in which the flange is completely drawn into the wall of the cup:
[$]\beta=D_{0} / d[/$].
}}

A larger blank diameter would result in {{c2::failure of the material}}.

Deep drawing {{c3::is not::is/is not}} a universal tool like bending or rubber forming. {{c3::(as it requires several dies for one part)}}

The tooling costs for the deep drawing process are {{c1::not low, but not very high either}}.

The optimum product series is around {{c2::10k-100k}}. In the aerospace industry it's only used when there's no alternative.

In {{c1::explosive}} forming, you have your workpiece placed in {{c5::water::material}}, on top of a {{c4::female::male/female}} die.

In the water, you detonate an explosive, and {{c3::shock waves}} form.

The {{c2::pressure pulse}} then bends the workpiece as desired.

In explosive forming, one production cycle takes {{c1::tens of minutes::time unit}} or even {{c1::hours::time unit}}. 

Explosive forming is used for {{c1::small}} product series.

Some advantages of explosive forming are:

Cheap {{c1::tooling. Only one (female) die is needed, which can be made of cheap materials as it'll only be used for a small production series.::t...}}

Almost no limit to {{c3::the sheets to be deformed, not in {{c2::size}} or {{c2::thickness}}. There's always a heavier bomb to use.}}

The explosive forming takes advantage of the {{c4::strain rate sensitivity::property}} of metal alloys.
{{c4::Most metal alloys are strain rate sensitive: if the strain rate increases, so do the yield and failure strength, meaning more complex shapes can be achieved.}}

Some disadvantages of explosive forming are:

The process requires special {{c1::production sites::pro...}}, special {{c1::trained personnel::per...}}, and a lot of {{c1::licenses::li...}} and {{c1::permits::per...}}, before actual production may start.

The product series is {{c2::limited}}, on the order of {{c2::100}} products.

The cycle time is {{c3::very long}}.

Explosive forming is an {{c4::universal}} process, as it only requires one product-specific die.

The die is often made from {{c1::cheap::property}} but {{c2::shock resistant::property}} materials like {{c3::steel}} and {{c3::concrete}}.
Most products made by explosive forming are {{c1::shell}} type products: {{c1::double curved sheets with large radii}}.
In {{c1::superplastic}} forming, {{c2::no change::a change/no change}} in the shape of the crystals of the metal alloy is visible because {{c3::they slide/glide along each other}}.

Only few alloys show superplastic behaviour. The required material features are:


Forming at {{c1::high}} temperatures:
{{c1::the temperature needs to be high but not quite melting yet, otherwise it'd be casting}}

{{c2::Equi-axed}} grain structure:
the grains should have {{c2::similar}} dimensions in all directions

{{c3::Stable}} grain structure at {{c4::high}} temperature:
{{c3::an alloy should not recrystallize at {{c4::high}} temperatures.}}

High {{c5::strain rate}} sensitivity at specific {{c5::strain rates}} (often low):
{{c5::At very specific strain rates, the material shows superplastic behaviour. If you strain it at a faster rate, it's no longer superplastic for some reason. As it's usually a small strain rate at which superplastic behaviour can be observed cycle time goes from the order of 10s to 100s of minutes.}}

Although large strains are a big advantage for forming processes, there are some disadvantages in superplastic forming:

{{c3::Cavitation}}: due to {{c2::the gliding of grains}}, {{c1::small mismatches}} may occur, resulting in tiny {{c3::cavities}}. These may grow and even link up when the deformation continues, having detrimental effects on material properties.

Excessive {{c4::thinning}}: the deformations are dominated by {{c5::tensile}} and {{c6::stretching}} strains. This may make the sheet very, very {{c4::thin}}.

During superplastic forming the flow stresses are {{c2::very low::magnitude}} because of the {{c3::high}} operating temperatures.

Therefore, {{c1::gas::source of}} pressure is sufficient to stretch the material into the {{c4::female::male/female}} die.
{{c2::Superplastic}} forming can create {{c1::strains}} between {{c3::200-1000}}%, even up to {{c3::6000-7000}}%

Superplastic forming...

Has {{c1::high::high/low}} costs because the equipment, both the machines and the dies, should sustain {{c2::the high temperatures and moderate pressures}}.

Has a {{c3::long::long/short}} process cycle.

Has a typical product series size of about {{c4::a few hundred}}.

In bulk forming, the input material has three different names:

{{c1::Slug::S...}}
{{c2::Billet::B...}}
{{c3::Pre-form::P...}}
The process of forming bulks is called {{c1::forging}}.
Forging can be done either hot or cold - higher temperatures lead to {{c2::lower::higher/lower}} {{c1::required forces}} and {{c2::higher::higher/lower}} {{c1::failure strains}}.

In {{c1::open-die}} forming, the workpiece is simply pressed by two dies; by placing the dies differently, the desired shape may be obtained.

It should be noted that frictional forces create {{c2::barrelling}}; use of lubricants may help prevent this.

During {{c1::impression-die}} forging, the dies are already pre-shaped.

Note that the amount of material needed to fill the cavity between the two dies cannot be accurately obtained.

Therefore, a {{c2::flash}} (squeeze out material) is present after forging, which is removed by trimming operations.
Forging is not suitable for {{c1::thin walled}} parts nor for parts with large {{c2::thickness variations}}.

In forging,

Thin walled parts can only be obtained by large deformations, but those deformations {{c1::cools}} the material very quickly, thereby changing its properties, and thus making it difficult to complete the thinning.

{{c2::Cracks}} and {{c3::tearing}} will arise when the material can not meet the required deformations. High {{c4::internal stresses}} can also occur.

Three kinds of presses are used in forging:

{{c1::Hydraulic presses}} are {{c4::load}} limited:
they press until a certain maximum {{c4::pressure}} is reached, but the length of the stroke doesn't matter.
They are relatively slow however, and the material cools down quickly unless the dies are heated.

{{c2::Mechanical presses}} are {{c5::stroke}} limited.
A flywheel is used to store the energy applied for the forcing process.

{{c3::Hammers}} are {{c6::energy}} limited.
They operate at high speeds, resulting a short process time. Therefore, the cooling rate is low, which allows for complex shapes.

Concerning some material considerations in forging:

Most forging operations are done at elevated {{c1::temperatures}}, so the die materials should be able to withstand those.

{{c2::Mechanical}} and {{c3::thermal}} shock resistance are important, as is {{c4::wear}} resistance.

{{c5::Shrinking::mechanical process}} of the product needs to be taken into account

{{c6::Draft}} angles should once more be used to facilitate retrieval of the final product from the dies.

{{c7::Lubrication::L...}} may be used to reduce friction and wear.
{{c7::This also acts as thermal barrier between the hot material and the colder dies (so that the dies don't become too hot (which would increase wear) and the material doesn't cool down too much), and finally they make sure that the material doesn't stick to the dies}}.

Compared to casting, which liquefies the metal, forging stretches the grain pattern of the metal alloy {{c1::locally}}, resulting in {{c2::fibrous}} grains, which are usually {{c3::parallel}} to the products' surfaces.

This grain structure (texture) is considered favourable for {{c4::corrosion}} and {{c5::fatigue}} resistance.

The reason for this is that when forging is performed at an elevated temperature, the process induces {{c7::internal stresses}} in the part as a result of the {{c6::non-uniform cooling of the material}}.

The {{c9::inner::inner/outer}} parts of the material will remain hot for a {{c8::longer::longer/shorter}} time than the {{c9::outer::inner/outer}} surfaces.

Consequentially, there will be {{c10::tensile}} stresses in the inner parts and {{c10::compressive}} stresses near the surface, which is often favourable for enhancement of {{c11::fatigue}} properties.

Costs for forging are generally speaking relatively {{c2::high::high/low}}.

The series length is limited by the {{c1::die}} life, which ranges in the order of 10k-50k pieces.

In the aerospace industry, forged parts for use in critical applications are often produced {{c3::in several steps, increasing the costs::all at once/in several steps}}.
Still, it's better than casting for example, due to the possibility to produce high-strength parts with good fatigue properties.
{{c1::Extrusion}} is the pulling through of metal at elevated temperatures through a die.

In extrusion:

A metal {{c1::billet}} is squeezed through an opening with a constant cross-sectional shape.

This allows you to create e.g. a very long stringer with constant cross-sectional shape.

The process temperature depends on the metal alloy, typical values for aluminium extrusion are {{c2::375C - 475C::degrees C}}.

Usually, the die is a {{c3::disk::shape}}. Lubrication is often used to lower friction forces.

The scale of the cross-section of an extrusion is given by the {{c1::Circumscribing Circle Diameter (CCD)}}, which is the diameter of the smallest circle enclosing the profile, typically between 2 cm and 25 cm.

The complexity of the profile is given by the {{c2::shape}} factor, which relates the surface area per unit mass.

Metal alloys, in particular aluminium alloys, are very suitable for extrusion.

The deformations occurring in the metal alloy tend to be the highest near the {{c1::walls}} of the extrusion; the grains in the extrusion are stretched, so the mechanical properties will be different in this direction.

A small amount of {{c2::anisotropic}} behaviour is thus introduced in the metal extrusion.

It should be noted that {{c3::steel::metal type}} alloys are not as well suited as {{c3::aluminium::metal type}} alloys, as they require a larger {{c4::force}} and {{c4::temperature}}, resulting in higher tooling cost.

Metal extrusion can create hollow, semi-hollow and solid profiles. This is done in two ways:

a) The billet already contains a hole and the {{c1::mandrel}} is there to create a hole; the metal flows around the {{c1::mandrel}}.

b) A bridge with a {{c1::mandrel}} nose is welded to the die. The material flows past the bridge and surrounds the {{c1::mandrel}} nose.

a)
b)
Composites consist of {{c1::fibres}} as {{c1::reinforcing}} elements and {{c2::polymers}} as {{c2::resin or matrix material}} between the {{c1::fibres}}.

For composites:

The {{c2::fibres}} provide {{c1::strength}} and {{c1::stiffness}},

the polymer provides support of {{c2::fibres}},

{{c3::load}} transfer between {{c2::fibres}} by {{c3::shear}},

{{c4::protection::pr...}} of {{c2::fibres}},

and gas/liquid {{c5::tightness::ti...}} of products.

For composites:

{{c1::Glass::Material}} fibres are often used if weight doesn't matter; {{c1::carbon::material}} fibres are used if weight matters (but are more expensive).

For {{c1::thermoset}} polymers, the process of the {{c2::monomers}} (which the polymer consists of) reacting and {{c3::cross linking::cr...}} (where things like {{c4::H-bridges}} appear between the {{c2::monomers}}) is called {{c5::curing}}.

The {{c6::higher::higher/lower}} the temperature, the {{c7::faster::faster/slower}} the {{c1::thermoset}} polymer cures.

{{c1::Prepegs}} are {{c2::partially cured fibre reinforced thermosets}}.

{{c1::Prepregs}} are stored at low temperatures to prevent further {{c3::cross linking}}.

Usual allowable storage times are between {{c4::0.5 and 1::duration}} year(s).
{{c1::Thermoplastic}} polymers consist of monomers and contain several large molecular chains connected by {{c2::weak secondary}} bonds.
These bonds are much more easily broken than H-bridges.

Thermoplastics have {{c1::infinite allowable::duration}} storage times.

Their processing temperatures are much {{c2::higher::higher/lower}} than that of thermosets.

Thermoplastic polymer viscosities are much {{c3::higher (a factor 10E5 higher)::higher/lower}} than those of thermosets.

For composites:

The rule of mixtures may be used to estimate {{c1::some::some/all}} of the parameters of the composite.
(though not all of them, e.g. properties involving plasticity).
The difference between {{c2::liquid phase processing}} and {{c3::solid phase processing (or forming)}} when working with polymers is the {{c1::length of the fibres used}}.

The liquid case requires the fibres to be short, i.e. smaller than 1mm: the flow of the polymers is dominant as the fibres are so small.

For physical processing, the fibres then dominate.

{{c1::Lay-up}} is the general process of {{c2::laying fibres on top of each other.

It is typically used for materials that have a textile appearance, such as woven fabrics.

Individual layers of reinforcement ({{c3::lamina}} or {{c4::ply}}) can be cut to the required shape from a very large roll of material, and subsequentially assembled {{c4::ply-by-ply}} into a {{c3::laminate}}.
}}

In the lay-up process, long fibers are inserted into a thermoset resin, which is then cured.
There are two methods of doing this:

a) {{c5::Pre-impregnate the fibers with the resin very well in advance (prepreg)}} so that you have partially cured fibre composite thermosets.
In this case the polymerization is easily achieved by curing in an oven or {{c3::autoclave}}.
This method has the advantages of being tacky enough to prevent slipping in the mould, and the resin even acting as lubricant.

b) However, one can also {{c4::wait with adding resin until just before it goes onto the mould}}, this is called {{c2::dry reinforcement}}.
This is {{c1::cheaper::more expensive}} than using method a).

As moulds are used during lay-up, the product must be separated once cured, and thus {{c1::draft}} angles are very common.

Multiple moulds may be used, but these do lead to undesirable {{c2::flash}} lines in the product.

The products produced are mostly {{c3::thin}}-walled {{c3::shell}}-like structures. Stiffening elements such as hat stiffeners can also be applied to these {{c3::shells}}.

{{c4::Sandwich}} structures also made via this process.

The lay-up mould may be made of {{c1::wood::material}}, {{c1::cast epoxy::material}} or {{c1::metal::material}}, depending on the number of products to be made and whether the tool is also used to cure the part at elevated temperatures or not.

The lay-up process has relatively:

{{c1::Low}} equipment costs for hand laying
{{c1::Moderate to high}} equipment costs for Automatic Tape Laying

{{c2::Low}} mould costs

{{c3::High}} labour costs for hand laying
{{c3::Low to moderate}} labour costs for Automatic Tape Laying

{{c4::High}} raw material costs (since fibres are {{c5::very expensive::cheap/expensive}})
In {{c1::filament winding}}, a single, very long continuous fibre is {{c2::pulled through the resin and wound about a mould to make woven fabric}}.
{{c1::Pulltrusion}} is extrusion applied to {{c2::composites::type of material}}.

After lay-up, the reinforcement/resin combination needs to be cured to merge into a composite part.

The resin manufacturer specifies the required process conditions for curing; {{c1::increased::increased/decreased}} temperature and {{c1::increased::increased/decreased}} pressure lead to the {{c1::highest::highest/lowest}} quality products.

For that aim, an {{c2::autoclave}} is used, {{c1::which can withstand temperatures of 150 C - 200 C and 10 - 15 bars, respectively}}.

In autoclaving,

The high temperature is needed to {{c1::speed up the cure process}} and for the {{c2::adequate performance level of the composite}}.

The high pressure is needed to {{c3::compact and consolidate the laminate}} and to {{c4::reduce the voids to a minimum by pressuring out the air}}.

{{c1::Resin Transfer Moulding (RTM)}} is another process used in solid phase polymer forming.

The fibres are laid out in a mould.

You then close the mould by placing another mould on top of it.

A tube is connected to the cavity between the two moulds containing the fibres; the liquid resin is pumped into this, until it filled the cavity completely and flows from the exit (called outlet).

Subsequently, the resin is cured.

In Resin Transfer Moulding:

Resin will only flow if a pressure difference exists.

The pressure difference can be accomplished by {{c1::pressuring the resin}} and/or {{c1::applying a vacuum at the outlet}};
doing so, pressure differences of several bars can be achieved.

An advantage of increased pressure difference is the increase in resin flow speed, but a too fast resin flow can {{c2::move reinforcement fibres unexpectedly}}, leading to scrap or time-consuming repairs.

A higher pressure difference also increases the {{c3::mould closing forces}}. So, higher {{c3::clamping forces}} means either needing a larger {{c4::press}} (higher cost) or limits the {{c5::product sizes}}.

Nonetheless, RTM takes place at lower pressures than compression moulding or rubber forming, so the required {{c3::clamping force}} is still considerably lower compared to those processes.

In Resin Transfer Moulding, there are some material considerations:

To accomplish low {{c1::cycle times}}, the tooling materials must be capable to be uniformly heated to about {{c4::90 C - 150 C::temperature range}}.

Traditionally, {{c3::metals}} have been used as materials to make the moulds;
these have the disadvantage that they are difficult to make, heavy to use and the thermal expansion coefficients are different, which has undesirable effects on the quality of the finished product.

Therefore, some preliminary tests have been performed to manufacture moulds using {{c2::epoxies}}.

In Resin Transfer Moulding, there are some material considerations:

The {{c1::ease of the flow}} of the resin dominates the choice of resin.

Minimum {{c1::viscosity}} is desired, as are the {{c2::time}} and {{c2::temperature}} at which the resin will retain this {{c1::viscosity}} (also called {{c3::pot life}}), as well as the expected {{c4::permeability}} of the reinforcement (which should be as {{c5::high::high/low}} as possible).

Generally speaking, {{c7::thermoplastics::type of polymer}} {{c6::can not::can/can not}} be used for RTM. {{c6::(although people are trying to make it work)}}

In Resin Transfer Moulding, there are some material considerations:

Regarding the reinforcements, the reinforcement usually consists of weaves and mats (chopped-strand) of fibre material.

Since the reinforcement is placed into the mould before resin is added, the reinforcement needs to be formed from an initial flat shape into the three-dimensional shape of the mould. This is called {{c1::preform}}.

The {{c2::permeability}} of the reinforcement is also important: similar to the mechanical properties, the {{c2::permeability::pe...}} of the reinforcements is {{c3::anisotropic}}, greatly influencing the resin flow pattern.
