Special caution has to be taken to avoid {{c5::non-impregnated areas (named {{c4::dry spots}})}}. The {{c3::anisotropic}} behaviour makes it difficult to predict the flow of the resin.

Finally, the {{c6::porosity::po...}} of the reinforcement is important. {{c6::Porosities}} are filled by the resin, so the more {{c6::porosities}}, the longer the fill time.

Since the Resin Transfer Moulding process enables the production of components in a single injection cycle, {{c1::product size}} is normally not a limiting factor.

However, the inlets and outlets need to be placed properly, otherwise unwanted {{c2::resin-free regions}} will develop.

RTM is a {{c3::slow::fast/slow}} process, and therefore product series are usually {{c4::small::large/small}}.

Resin Transfer Moulding has relatively:

{{c1::Low}} equipment costs
{{c2::Low to moderate}} mould costs
{{c3::Moderate}} labour costs
{{c4::High}} raw material costs

If no {{c2::pressured resin}} is used in Resin Transfer Moulding, but only {{c2::a vacuum at the outlet}}, then the process is called {{c1::vacuum infusion}}.

{{c2::

As only vacuum related forces are applied, one of the two moulds can be replaced by a {{c3::foil}}; this will result in a part with only one smooth surface, but the tooling costs will decrease.

A major advantage of the vacuum infusion process is that the {{c5::size}} of the product is {{c4::unlimited}}.

However, because low-cost materials are used in mould construction, mould pressures must be low, but they result in long {{c6::fill times}} and limited {{c6::fibre contents}}.

The inability of the mould to tolerate {{c7::elevated temperatures}} and its poor {{c7::heat transfer}} results in long cure times.

}}

In the forming of fibre reinforced thermoplastics, there are two methods to circumvent the low failure strain of fibres.

In {{c1::intraply shear}}, we {{c3::{{c1::shear}} the individual plys (a ply is a layer of fibres), and the deformation happens within it.}}

The squares become diamonds, of which the surface area decreases, but the material is not disappearing, so the thickness will increase.

The limiting factor is the {{c2::locking angle}}, which is the maximum a fabric can {{c1::shear}}.

In the forming of fibre reinforced thermoplastics, there are two methods to circumvent the low failure strain of fibres.

Interply slip is when {{c1::
we stack multiple plys on top each other, and they slip relative to each other.

For this slipping to occur the layers need to be {{c2::heated}}, so they can deform independently from each other.

If not, the layers willl start to {{c3::buckle}} or {{c3::fold}} locally.
}}

For {{c2::short and long}} fibres, the {{c1::resin}} dominates the fabrication.

For {{c2::continuous}} fibres, the {{c1::fibre}} dominates the fabrication.

Press forming operations for FRTP (forming of reinforced thermoplastics) are performed on presses similar to the ones used in the forming of sheet metal.
There are two striking differences however:

In FRTP, a heating unit is present, to heat the thermoplastic resin above its {{c1::glass transition}} temperature {{c1::[$]T_{g}[/$]}}, where the thermoplastic becomes {{c1::soft and rubber-like material}}.

In FRTP, no matching dies (i.e. two dies with a particular gap width as desired by the design of the sheet) are used. Due to the {{c2::Trellis}} effect (also known as {{c2::intraply shear}}) the {{c3::thickness}} of the laminates may change considerably over the surface of the part, so you'd cause damage if you use a constant gap between the dies.

For FRTP (forming of reinforced thermoplastics): 

In case of {{c4::long}} fibres, the {{c1::resin}} dominates and an {{c2::elevated temperature}} is needed to activate the flow of the thermoplastic polymer.

In case of {{c4::continuous}} fibres, an {{c2::elevated temperature}} is needed, and in this case the deformation mechanism is based on the {{c3::intra- and inter-ply shear}} mechanisms. The polymer must be 'soft' enough to follow the fibre movements/rotations.

The deformation modes of FRTP (forming of reinforced thermoplastics) is different from the modes used in metal sheet, so the geometrical aspects of parts will also be different.

For {{c2::continuous}} fibres, the main deformation mechanism is {{c1::intra-ply shear}}, which have geometrical changes similar to the so-called deep drawing deformation. Biaxial straining is not possible.

The geometrical complexity of FRTP with {{c2::long}} fibres is limited by the size of the part, the fibre volume content, the viscosity of the polymer, etc., as {{c3::the flow of the polymer}} is the main deformation mechanism.

For FRTP (forming of reinforced thermoplastics):

The costs are comparable to metal forming, but they are much {{c1::lower::higher/lower}} than the costs of similar composite parts with thermosets.

The main reason is that thermoplastics can be manufactured as {{c2::laminates::type of product structure}}, stored like a metal, and cut and formed like a metal with press forming equipment.

{{c1::Thermoset based composites are laminated on a mould and cured in special ovens or autoclaves, and have limited storage life.}}

For {{c2::compression}} moulding, two rigid and matched dies are used; since this tooling is very expensive, it is required that the product series is large, so it's not used in aerospace, but is used in automotive. This method can be applied to both {{c1::short}} and {{c1::long}} fibres.

Note that since you're compressing so much, the fibre orientation will be random.

Some of the defining aspects of Additive Manufacturing (AM) regarding its costs are:

There is no {{c3::tooling}} needed, so the {{c3::tooling}} cost vanishes [$]\left(C_{T}=0\right)[/$].

The {{c1::production rate}} [$]\dot{n}[/$] is very {{c2::slow::slow/fast}} for [$]\mathrm{AM}[/$], as it's a very {{c2::slow::slow/fast}} process. This means that the {{c5::equipment}} cost and {{c6::overhead}} cost are generally very {{c2::large::large/small}}.

For high-end AM processes, the {{c4::equipment}} cost [$]C_{C}[/$] is large.

The {{c7::material}} cost [$]P_{m}[/$] is usually {{c8::large::large/small}} for AM compared to traditional manufacturing processes.

Additive manufacturing is best suited for products which have {{c2::high}} complexity and {{c3::small}} product series sizes.

This is because of the location of the {{c1::breakeven}} points compared to traditional manufacturing.

Some advantages of Additive Manufacturing are:

{{c1::Changing}} or {{c1::revising}} the product is easy; you don't need to change your whole dedicated tooling.

It reduces {{c2::waste}}.

It's easier to produce {{c3::replacement}} parts.

Some shapes are only possible to manufacture using AM (e.g. porous materials - stuff with very small holes in them, or very complexly shaped parts like exhausts on a car).

The most popular AM technique is the {{c2::Fused Deposition Modelling (FDM)}} method, where a {{c4::continuous filament of a thermoplastic polymer is used to 3D print layers of materials.

The filament is {{c1::heated}} at the nozzle to reach a {{c1::semi-liquid}} state and then {{c1::extruded}} on the platform or on top of previously printed layers.

The {{c3::thermoplasticity::property}} allows the polymer to solidify together when it returns to room temperature.
}}

Note that we distinguish two materials: one will be used for the actual part; the other is support material and will be removed later, but is necessary during printing to create supports for overhangs.

The downside of these support structures is that the edges where you remove the supports won't look very smooth (plus the fact that it needs to be post-processed to begin with).

In AM, specifically Fused Deposition Modelling,

If you only care about the outer shape of a product, the inside {{c1::can::can/can't}} be left relatively {{c2::empty}}. If the product has to carry loads, the filling {{c3::can::can/can't}} only use rectangular shapes.

{{c3::You can also use triangles or honeycombs.}}

In AM, specifically Fused Deposition Modelling,

If you only care about the outer shape of a product, and post-processing such as sanding and chemical smoothing is required, it's usually good to increase the {{c1::shell thickness}} a bit, since those techniques reduce the {{c1::thickness of the surface}}.

{{c1::Shells should be at least a few {{c2::nozzle diameters}} thick, since else you get voids.}}

The Fused Deposition Modelling technique also exists for metals, but then you use metal powder that's melted and deposited on the surface of a plate/product.

You use a laser to ensure you have sufficient heat to melt the powder, and this method is called {{c1::Laser Deposition Technology (LDT)}}.

The second most popular technique in Additive Manufacturing is {{c1::photopolymerisation}}, also known as {{c1::stereolithography (SLA)}}.

The basic idea is pretty simple: you have an basin filled with liquid resin.

Using an {{c3::UV::EM frequency band}}-laser and some mirrors, you point exactly at the areas that you want to {{c2::solidify}} (photosensitive polymers {{c2::solidify}} when subjected to {{c3::UV::EM frequency band}} radiation).

Once the top of the resin has {{c2::solidified}}, you move the piston and platform a tiny bit down, and create a new layer of material by pointing your {{c3::UV::EM frequency band}}-laser at different stuff.

Doing this over and over again (each layer is like [$]10 \mu \mathrm{m}[/$] thick) will eventually result in a layered part.

Believe it or not, it's quite accurate. Note that the amount of waste is minimal, since the resin can just be reused.

There are some inaccuracies introduced by stereolithography (or photopolymerisation):

{{c3::Overcuring}}, when an overhang parts {{c3::overcures}} since there is no fusing with a bottom layer.

The resin is a high-viscosity liquid, so the {{c1::layer thickness}} is a bit variable.

The {{c2::scanning}} of the laser may be apparent.

For stereolithography:

The main advantages are:
- Very {{c1::smooth}} surface.
- Fine {{c2::resolution}}
- High {{c3::quality}}

Disadvantages are:
- Only very {{c4::limited}} materials are suitable
- Slow {{c5::production process}}
- High {{c6::costs}}

{{c1::Selective laser melting (SLM)}}, also called {{c1::selective laser sintering (SLS)}} is a technique where compacted fine powders such as metals, alloys, polymers and ceramics are laser-heated, akin to SLA.

In Selective Laser Sintering, we want to achieve the right scan speed for a specific laser power.

Low scan speeds lead to {{c1::overmelting}} and subsequent {{c2::bubble formation}}.

High speeds lead to {{c1::undermelting}} and subsequent {{c2::incomplete part attachment}}.

In general, thermal fluctuations during Selective Laser Sintering may cause {{c1::residual stress}}. This may be solved in various ways:

{{c2::
Heat treatment: the part is heated up for like an hour to relieve stress.
::He...}}

{{c3::
Rescanning of laser: you may just re-apply the laser to relieve some residual stresses.
::Re-....}}

{{c4::Heating of the powder bed: if the powder bed is of a higher temperature, then the cooling happens more gradually.::Pow...}}

{{c5::Sectoral scanning: this strategy breaks down a layer into small square grids and neighbouring grids are scanned perpendicular to one another.::Sect...}}

The difference between stereolithography and selective laser melting is that {{c1::SLA is more accurate}}.

Additionally, polymers are much {{c2::cheaper::more expensive/cheaper}} than metals (on the order of 10x).

{{c12::Electron beam melting}} (EBM), also called {{c13::direct energy deposition}} (DED), {{c14::laser engineered net shaping}} (LENS), {{c15::electron beam additive manufacturing}} (EBAM) or {{c16::laser metal deposition}} (LMD), is a technique where {{c1::compacted fine powders such as metals, alloys, polymers and ceramics are heated using electron laser beams.}}

Main advantages are:
- Reduced {{c2::manufacturing time}} and {{c3::cost}}
- Excellent {{c4::mechanical}} properties
- Controlled {{c5::microstructure}}
- Accurate {{c6::composition}} control
- Excellent for {{c7::repair::re...}} and {{c7::retrofitting::re...}}

Disadvantages are:
- Low {{c8::accuracy}}
- Low {{c9::surface}} quality
- Need for a {{c10::support}} structure
- Limitation in printing {{c11::complex}} shapes with {{c11::fine details}}.

{{c1::Binder jetting}}, also called {{c2::inkjet}} printing or {{c3::contour}} crafting, is a technique in which {{c4::layer by layer, carefully some binder material is deposited at the desired locations for each powder layer. 

Common materials are {{c5::ceramic::cer...}}, {{c5::concrete::con...}} and {{c5::soil::so...}}.

Main advantages are:
- Ability to print {{c6::large}} structures.
- {{c7::Quick::speed}} printing.

Disadvantages are:
- Maintaining {{c8::workability}}.
- Coarse {{c9::resolution}}.
- Lack of {{c10::adhesion}} between layers.
- Layers are clearly finished {{c11::layer-by-layer::visual property}}.
}}

{{c1::Laminated object}} processes involve {{c2::cutting each layer before bonding it to the existing product.

It can be applied to polymer composites, ceramics, paper, metal-filled tapes and metal rolls.

Main advantages are
- Reduced {{c3::tooling}} and {{c4::manufacturing time}}
- A vast range of {{c5::materials}} is possible
- Low {{c6::cost}}
- Excellent for manufacturing of {{c7::large}} structures

Disadvantages are
- Inferior {{c8::surface}} quality and {{c9::dimensional}} accuracy
- Limitation in manufacturing of {{c10::complex}} shapes
}}
It's used for e.g. paper manufacturing, foundry industries, electronics and smart structures.

The five main use cases of additive manufacturing in aerospace applications are:

{{c1::Part manufacturing::Man...}}
Rapid {{c3::prototyping::pro...}}
Rapid {{c2::tooling::too...}}
{{c4::Geometry repair::Geo...}}
{{c5::Topology optimisation::Top...}}

AM isn't perfect and suffers from some drawbacks.

First and foremost, the main limitation is that there is quite a large {{c1::uncertainty}} with respect to material {{c1::performance::per...}}.
This is because the {{c2::spot size}} of the laser (when e.g. using SLM) can have large variation depending on the energy source power, metallic powder, etc.

{{c3::Residual}} stresses thus exist as a result of melting and sintering.
This can be solved by e.g. annealing.

The surface may also not always look very nice.
This may be solved by e.g. {{c7::chemical}} etching {{c7::(applying some chemicals to smoothen the surface and removing sharp edges).}}

Another process for surface smoothness is {{c4::shot peening}}, where you shoot tiny bits of material on a part, to produce tiny surface {{c6::plastic deformations}} that produce a compressive residual stress layer on the surface.
This prevents propagation of {{c5::microcracks}} from the surface. Stating the obvious but you shouldn't use both methods sequentially cause it'd kinda defeat each other's point.
